item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: blackocean
item.description:
For FL, I also acquired Serum (great plugin btw) and I sat my self down for 8 hours justin making synth sounds, so i have a pretty large library of sounds I like to use. I also spent a lot of time on splice.com downloading samples that fit my style perfectly. I took the time to have everything prepared, and I use it in almost the same way as Auxy. I have my drum kit folders, and my Serum presets organized into genre. Definitely recommend doing this for large DAWs. Let’s not forgot how well Auxy nails this concept. Having everything ready so you don’t let technicals block you is an amazing thing to boost creativity.

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
oh yeah, i think its a great daw and what i mainly use for producing stuff. It pretty much has anything you need for producing, though it might be hidden away somewhere or need a bit of exercise to figure out (though i really wish they would bring back the ducker or add a way to sidechain b/c attempting to automate that sh*t for every kick and/or snare for every instrument used is wayyy too much)
(also shameless plug + some private WIP’s)
https://soundcloud.com/m_x_c_n/tracks

https://soundcloud.com/m_x_c_n/munstas-wip-or-something-1/s-p07MH

https://soundcloud.com/m_x_c_n/another-track-1-remix-wip-1/s-NmiFi
(was supposed to be a halloween release, but didn’t get the chance to work on it so rip)

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
+1 @Auxy +1 @lowey

Same here. I like that I don’t have to worry about plugins and EQ and file management and keyboards and time and patch cables and blah blah blah. I love Reason. If I had the time, i’d probably be using it. But maybe not, the last song I wrote on there took almost two weeks, and I’m really happy with it, but I’m just as happy with (if not more so) with what I’ve been doing in Auxy over these last few weeks.

I 100% agree with you guys though. Sometimes the limitless options of the desktop DAW is overwhelming and the next thing I know i’ve auditioning snare sounds for the last hour or tweaking a filter chain lol…

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: lowey
item.description:
Auxy:

When I sit down at a computer with a massive DAW, I tend to get into my engineering mindset

This. Totally. I’ve always had the same problem: endlessly tinkering with synths trying to find a sound I like, messing with effect chains to find something different and cool, then never actually writing any bloody music. I like that Auxy has limited sounds. I spend more time thinking musically and less time thinking technically.

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: Auxy
item.description:
I started out with Cubase back in the nineties. Since then I’ve worked on projects in Reason, ProTools, Logic and Ableton Live. All these DAWs are fantastic tools with similar features but slightly different designs.

Even though I have access to and understand all these apps, I never felt particularly creative with any of them. When I sit down at a computer with a massive DAW, I tend to get into my engineering mindset. This has been great in situations where I for instance worked on studio recordings with bands.

The problem for me has always been that whenever I felt like making my own music (you know the feeling of having a groove or melody in your head), these apps tend to kill my creativity. I tend to get bored before I get much music done, and the groove in my head is lost to thoughts about which plugins I should use and how to route the signals.

This is why we started Auxy. To build a tool that lets you be creative with state of the art technology, without letting that technology (and too many choices) kill your ideas on the way.

Of course there are many people who are super creative using DAWs and other gear, but we’ve been happy to hear many stories from people who say they make more and better music with Auxy than they ever did with a DAW.

So my recommendation is to explore different tools and see which setup is right for your creativity and aspirations!

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: Ninjendo
item.description:
Ableton Live is great and I’ve been using it for about 2 weeks now. Workflow is smooth since its loop based. Plugins are great, also sounds. If you like Live, get standard. Buy the license now and to get an upgrade to the new version for free. Not bad of a deal.

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: Zeph
item.description:
I personally like Logic Pro more than FL, I don’t know. It just doesn’t feel as intuitive to me. But yet I may be biased because I used Garageband before either.

Read full topic

item.title: Is FL Studio good?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
You can drive a Honda Civic, or a Lamborghini. They’re both cars, they’ll both get you from A to B. They’re two totally different experiences.

When you get into the world of desktop music software you’ve got quite a bit more power under the hood. VSTs expand your sonic palette, working with audio is a breeze and the tools available are very mature in most cases.

The real question is whether or not you’ve outgrown your software. In that case when you’ve pushed it to the limits it’s time to try something else maybe.

There’s a caveat to all this though… everything has a trade off. In my life right now I don’t have the time to sit down behind a desktop or laptop for hours on end writing music, I have two kids and a very full time career. So stuff like Auxy is a godsend. Hash your time to work on stuff against the content of what you’re writing and it helps to know what tools you wanna fill your toolbox with

Read full topic
